speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 14-857, Campbell-Ewald Company v. Gomez. Mr. Garre.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is there any controversy over whether the --  the --  the offer is complete relief?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do we take it on that assumption, too?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that's a merits question as to whether they're entitled to attorneys' fees. If the question is complete -- you know, "complete relief" means what the plaintiff has asked for. The plaintiff has asked for attorneys' fees here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, he would -- he would receive a finding of liability, which you didn't Alderson Reporting Company admit in your offer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: He would -- he would be entitled to an injunction against that activity, the activity that caused this particular situation, and if others were shown, to an injunction in other ways. So I don't see how this could be -- putting aside the class action, putting aside the attorneys' fees, those appear to me to be fairly critical liability determinations that were not made by the court below.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It -- it seems that you want us to write an -- an opinion saying that a settlement offer is equivalent to a judgment. And we've had cases, like the Kokkonen case, in which there was a Alderson Reporting Company settlement approved by the court, case dismissed, then the settlement was not performed. They went to court seeking an injunction. The court said, no, no. You have a contract. You have to file again. You have to go into a different court. You have to start all over again. A settlement offer and a settlement contract and a settlement agreement are different from a judgment, and you do not have a judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you didn't pursue that. You didn't apply under the rules for a judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and -- and if you want us to write an opinion and say, oh, well, a settlement offer is the same as a judgment, that just doesn't accord with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure or with our cases like the Kokkonen case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the Federal rule in point, Mr. Garre -- and it says -- Rule says an offer of judgment expires automatically after days if it's not accepted. It is deemed withdrawn, and it cannot be used for any purpose other than to saddle the plaintiff with costs if she doesn't get more than the offer. So we have a Federal rule directly in point, and that instructs litigants what an offer of judgment means. Why do we look any further than that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, isn't that rather an end run around the offer of judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The plaintiff -- the plaintiff asks for class action, didn't get that because Alderson Reporting Company they weren't far --  far along enough for the plaintiff even to move for certification.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the collective action is simply a device for permissive joinder. It's quite different, as Genesis recognized. Class action --  I don't remember Justice Thomas' exact words, but it's a whole different kettle of fish.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: All it --  all it is -- it's an invitation to people to join you. That's all -- all that --  it's a permissive joinder.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: One --  one is --  is that potential. The other is, it's not that I would be entitled to attorneys' fees from the loser, but if there's a class, then there are a lot of other people who will share in the attorneys' fees and I'll have to pay less.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But if I could go back a little bit, Mr. Garre. And this is, I think, the question that Justice Scalia started with. There are a number of things that you've said, well, he asked for it, but he's not entitled to it. He asked for attorneys' fees, but he's not entitled to attorneys' fees. And he asked for an injunction or declaratory relief, and he's not entitled to that. And he asked for class certification, but he's not entitled to that, and so the case is moot. And the "so the case is moot" seems to me to be a non sequitur. In other words, he's asked for these things, you haven't offered these things, and there's a dispute about whether he's entitled to these things. Now, you might be completely right as to that, "He's not entitled to attorneys' fees." But that has to be adjudicated. You can't --  a court can't just Alderson Reporting Company say, oh, you've offered complete relief, because in his view you haven't offered complete relief, and that's what the litigation is all about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: A court can absolutely make that determination. But the question is: Does the court make that determination in the guise of a mootness motion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why can't it --  why can't it do that in the context of a summary judgment motion? I mean, why does it have to moot the case? Wouldn't the appropriate vehicle be a summary judgment motion in which you admit the facts that make you liable, or you concede the facts that make you liable, and then you fight about the legal questions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But I -- but what's an Article III determination is whether he or it or she is entitled to the relief that they asked for. May well be they're not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But they're entitled to have the court say it, not you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: By the way, you called this a "freestanding offer," but I have it right here, and the -- offer says, "Offer of judgment pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68." This was your client's submission.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose one day after the offer the defendant defaulted. Would a case that's now -- was once moot now become non-moot?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It happened in Kokkonen. We had a case on it here in the Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: A substantive -- how about a procedural right to litigate entitlement to Alderson Reporting Company class status?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why is it that we permit relation back at all --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- if -- if we have cases that say when a case has become moot in the middle of the litigation, it can relate back to the beginning?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If mootness is mootness, mootness is mootness, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the -- what if the defendant -- I -- did you finish your answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the defendant has very shaky finances, maybe on the verge of bankruptcy, or has a history of reneging on promises, and -- but the -- the offer to provide full relief moots the case, even in that situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can the offer of complete relief from a solvent defendant where it looks like the relief will be forthcoming, if --  if you lose this case and so the case is not moot, could still be considered as a factor in the court's decision whether or not to certify the class?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In other words, the class certification goes along without reference to whether the lead plaintiff has any injury any longer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's why I asked if the trial judge could, in his discretion, consider that as a factor in certifying or not certifying --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You keep referring, but you -- multiple times in your brief and now twice -- but in the case that Judge Friendly dealt with, the class Alderson Reporting Company claims had already been done and dispensed with, distinguished, extinguished. So it wasn't a case of a class certification not yet ruled on; it was ruled on. The class action was out of the case. It was only the individual.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that's for future conduct, not -- not directed to the conduct -- the direct conduct at issue here. But I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I -- you know, I looked at the three railroad cases that you cited as proof that this has always been the case, but do you have anything besides those things? In the common law, I can't find any situation in which a court accepted a offer that wasn't accepted by the party. In the railroad cases, what they found was that an offer was made and the other side, by taking money, accepted the offer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Have you found any case in the common law that -- where there was an offer that was unaccepted, was entered by the court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you've had to -- you had to deposit the money in an account in the name of the plaintiff. And San Pablo turned on a provision of the California Civil Code that said an obligation for payment is extinguished, is extinguished by an offer of payment, if the money is immediately deposited in a reputable bank in the name of a creditor. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But Mr. Garre --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- and this is very much along the same lines -- you know, you -- you have an old English case. You have these three cases in the '90s, 1890s, which were really about liabilities had -- that had already been satisfied, and the court said, it's already been satisfied, payment has already been made. But there's really no history at all -- and tender Alderson Reporting Company offers have existed for a long, long time. There's no history at all of -- of saying that a tender offer moots a case, as opposed to the classic understanding, the common law understanding, of tender offers was that it created an incentive for parties, and that that was their purpose and that was their effect, was to incentivize parties to do something, but not to -- for -- not to provide a mechanism for a court just to throw out a case when a party decided that, for whatever reason, he thought that the tender offer was not good enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, but I -- I said that mootness is not the appropriate remedy in that case. The appropriate remedy in a case where it's absolutely clear that -- that the -- that the defendant has given -- has offered the plaintiff everything the plaintiff has asked for, which it's not in this case, but where it's absolutely clear, where the defendant has offered everything that the plaintiff himself has asked for, the appropriate thing to do, in order to prevent wasteful litigation, is not to dismiss the case for mootness, but to grant judgment in favor of the plaintiff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, it doesn't become moot. It's just been decided. It's -- there's been an adjudication at that point. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: There's nothing to dismiss.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, the only way that I see a court entering judgment in the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is a Rule judgment. Someone moves and says, you got everything you're entitled to. The other side comes back and says, no, I'm entitled to attorneys' fees, I'm entitled to whatever. And the court says, no, you're not; this is a full satisfaction; I enter judgment. I don't know why we have to make a merits determination based solely on an unaccepted offer of judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you do with the pleading rules that say payment and accord and satisfaction are affirmative defenses?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the personal stake that a would-be class representative has in getting a bonus or an --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How could he file a class action on your theory? That's what he wanted to do, and he was stopped very early on by this offer of judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, both sides have these class action policy arguments, but it's important not to let those drive this pretty technical mootness question. So if we could just take the class action arguments out of it. Alderson Reporting Company Just let's say that there's a plaintiff, and he claims 10,000 --  he wants $10,000 plus attorneys' fees, okay? And the defendant says, I'll give you $10,000. And the plaintiff says, no, I really want attorneys' fees, too. And the defendant says, no, you're not entitled to attorneys' fees. Plaintiff says, no, I think I am. I'll --  I think I --  I'm going to reject your settlement offer. So you say at that point the court can come in and say, oh, the case is moot. Now, how is that possible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: There's a --  there's a contested question as to what one person owes another. The --  the defendant has said he doesn't want to accept this offer because he doesn't think it gives him everything that's entitled --  he's entitled to. And the measure of complete relief has to be, at this stage, about what his complaint asks for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I suppose he could ask for the key to Fort Knox, right? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And then --  and then no -- no settlement offer would --  would suffice, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He could ask for a unicorn.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, then you would reject the case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Certainly --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: --  on the merits.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Don't you --  don't you think the court --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: There's a very --  there's a very easy response to this, which is: If it's frivolous, if it's trivial, you dismiss the case on the merits.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If it's a frivolous claim, I don't see why the Court can't dispose of that Alderson Reporting Company initially --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- in connection with the mootness --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Mitchell.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If there's no -- if you're getting everything you want, what is the case or controversy? What is the live dispute in which you have Alderson Reporting Company a personal stake toward the terms we use under Article III?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So -- well, what is it you're worried about, that they won't make good on the offer, or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose Mr. Garre right now were to take a big stack of cash out of his briefcase, or a certified check, and present that to you. Would there be any case left then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That would be -- there would be a case or controversy? If this were an individual Alderson Reporting Company action and the plaintiff had received from --  and --  and the damages are --  the --  the amount of potential damages are undisputed, and the --  the plaintiff has received that amount from the defendant, no dispute about it, there wouldn't be a live case or controversy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, why is there a live case or controvery? What is the controversy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Which would give the --  the defendant --  which would give the plaintiff what in addition to the money, under my hypothetical?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You're saying the defendant has --  has an interest --  pardon me --  that the plaintiff has an interest in the judgment -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- quite separate from obtaining all the relief that he requests.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Again -- again, why -- well, let -- let's assume the case in which they asked for $10,000 and $10,000 is deposited in a bank with irrevocable instructions to pay it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- what -- what is -- is the concrete injury, as the Chief Justice said, that results in adversity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm sorry. Go ahead.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Voluntary cessation Alderson Reporting Company can moot a case whether the plaintiff likes it or not, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, if it's certain that they're going to give you the money that you asked for, why isn't the same result applied? In other words, why is it not simply what the plaintiff wants? He doesn't want the money he's asking for; he wants a judgment that will give him the money. As far as I can tell, that's your argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But there has to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But there has to be adversity, as the Chief Justice mentioned in his first question. And if $10,000 is in the bank and he's been injured in the -- in the sum of $10,000, there's no adversity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Other -- other than the -- the -- the stigma of a judgment. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You put a lot of weight on what the plaintiffs -- but there's another interest here, which is the -- the court's interest. You're being given everything you want. You say, well, we've had a past injury. Well, you asked for relief on that, and that is what you're being given. And yet you say, nonetheless, we're entitled to enlist the court and the court's time. And not only that, Alderson Reporting Company under Article III, we're entitled to get a legal ruling, even though there's no --  there's nothing more that they can give you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You won't --  you won't take "yes" for an answer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's a -- that's a --  that's a factual question.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The district court said you were --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Page 40a?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No. Sorry. Sorry, counselor. That's not what it says. It's not "we assume for the sake of argument."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: "The parties do not dispute that defendant's Rule offer would have fully satisfied the individual claims asserted" --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: --  "or that could have been asserted by plaintiff in this action."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, did the Ninth Circuit proceed to decide the case on the basis of that factual finding?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Did the Ninth Circuit proceed to decide the case on the basis of the assumption that the district court factual determination Alderson Reporting Company was correct?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I think that is the same as proceed to decide for --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you're -- you're -- you're contrasting a forced entry of judgment on the one hand with mootness on the other. But a forced entry of judgment is one of the remedies for mootness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think -- I think when there has been a settlement and the parties have agreed to a settlement, the court can enter a judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even though the case is moot --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- because of the settlement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It isn't a judgment on the merits. It's -- it's -- it's a judgment affirming the settlement, affirming what the parties themselves have agreed to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't go to the merits of the claim.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- so just to be clear on the facts without getting into a dispute, let's say that the offer is for the -- all relief that you have asked for.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Not a question of what you think they're entitled to or what they think; Alderson Reporting Company everything you've asked for, including all attorneys' fees, so there's no question of cost-shifting or anything like that. All injunctive relief. They come to you and say, you write the injunction. You say there is still a case or controversy that could proceed to litigation.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What's --  what is the controversy? In the case I've hypothesized --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: --  what is the controversy?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I thought you said if the plaintiff is being obstreperous or whatever, you know, the --  just refusing to take it for spite or some reason. In that case? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And what would the judgment say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I thought that's what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: --  Mr. Garre was arguing. He said he'd need a judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And I take it that this judgment that you're talking about would be: He offered this. It's everything that you asked for. We are ordering that he pay it. And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: --  and --  and now the thing is dismissed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If the case is dead when there's --  when the judgment is entered, it seems to me it's even more dead when you've actually got the case in hand. If you have the judgment, you're going to --  you may have to enforce the judgment. You don't actually have anything of value. You have a piece of paper.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That's better - it's better to be --  if somebody gave you the choice between a judgment that says you're entitled to a certain amount of money and the money itself in your hand, you would rather have the judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But if you did. That was my first hypothetical. If you did, if you actually had the money in hand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. But it wouldn't be moot --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: My goodness. So every case has to be tried even when you've --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: --  been paid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's --  I want a judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you say it's not moot.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If, Mr. Garre, as you're leaving the courtroom today says, here, we will accept an entry of judgment; one, we'll make sure you get whatever attorneys' fees you want, and we will accept an entry of judgment, then the --  then the case would be over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Would it be over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, well, that's the whole thing; right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: This is all about Alderson Reporting Company class certification.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So the case comes down to, once we put away -- hypothesize that you're getting everything you, as the plaintiff in this case, has asked for, it all comes down to whether or not you can get the class certified.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you're saying --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you're saying --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Excuse me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you're saying that it's not because of the possibility that you could get a class certified.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: My hypothesis is you get everything else. Okay? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The only thing they don't say --  they enter a judgment. You want a judgment? Here's your judgment. You want all the attorneys' fees? Here's all your attorneys' fees. You want an injunction? You know, go ahead and write your injunction. But you say still not, because you might be able to be the representative plaintiff in a class action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't see why that one --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of course not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: --  would be a good --  the thing I thought was interesting here, and I wanted to know your position, is the AFL-CIO brief --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: --  which is on your side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you agree with it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I want to know: Do you agree with it? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. But why not? What they say is that the right way to go about this is -- and they cite cases and so forth in the nineteenth century --  is that the defendant should not --  you're right. It's not an offer of relief. What they say is the defendant is supposed to tender the money. And when he tenders the money, if the plaintiff won't accept it, he goes to the court and he deposits the money in the court. And the court then issues a judgment saying, this case is over. That's what I read here in pages to 11, and they have lots of authority, and that gets rid of the problem. And there's no --  it seems to me, well, if it isn't right, why isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Who --  what the judge does is say, they want $10,000. What the defendant does is he says, they won't take my check, which should be certified. So he deposits it in court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The judge at that point should say, the defendant has all he wants. The case is over. Goodbye. And, of course, if that person now has all he wants, he can't certify this is a class because he isn't harmed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. Give him judgment on the merits. Who cares?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, give me one. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not interested at the moment in the question asked. I am interested in the question I am asking. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And that isn't what I said. You now sound as if you are agreeing with the AFL-CIO.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, they don't say what the effect of it would be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What I want --  I'm being practical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the practical thing is that the defendant wants to pay off the plaintiff by giving him everything he wants.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there a way to do it? What they say is, yes, the way to do it is you tender the money in a certified check, and if he won't take it, pay the money into court. And the --  the judge then Alderson Reporting Company enters a judgment in favor of the plaintiff, who has gotten everything he asked for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Not the class certification. There's nothing in there that says --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, it's not a more complicated question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In my hypothetical, I'm saying, in those circumstances, do you agree -- do you or do you not agree, and if not, why not? The only thing that's left is, you'd like, says the plaintiff, class certification, or at least the lawyer would.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Even though there's been a certified check tendered to the plaintiff and a judgment has been entered giving -- saying the case is over because he's got everything he wants. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What is -- what is the financial stake here?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. Well, the cost -- so then that's fully satisfied if the offer covers attorneys' fees?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. Now, if --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What was the other one?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The incentive award?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You --  is there any concern that a plaintiff who has received or has been offered all relief that he could receive is an appropriate representative plaintiff of parties who have not gotten all the relief?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So the argument is that an individual plaintiff who has gotten everything that he has asked for --  and I realize you argue that isn't the case here.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: --  is --  is entitled Alderson Reporting Company to proceed with the litigation because he might get a bonus from a class action that he would like to lead?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I ask you just a practical question? Is Mr. Garre right that this is a case, if he were to proceed, if it were -- the class were certified and you get a judgment, this is a case where the class action attorneys are going to get a lot and the members of the class are going to get virtually nothing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You would have to -- you would have to prove that at the -- to establish damages, would you not, that the members of the class did not consent to receive these messages, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: How would you do that? How would you be able to -- how can you prove that Alderson Reporting Company somebody --  some member of the class at some point when they were agreeing to something on the internet didn't click a box that said, I agree to receive messages from all of, you know, a big class of senders?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What do you think the class members would get?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Individual class members. As a practical matter, what would they get at the end of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: A settlement? You're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if it's not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And you're going to be able to determine who did not --  prove that certain people did not consent? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you --  what do you do to get on that opt-in list?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We --  we haven't talked about the second issue that you raise, and one curiosity is the --  the actor that did something wrong was --  what is it? MindMatics?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you didn't sue. What is the reason that you went after the contractor only?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you're relying on vicarious liability?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Mitchell. Mr. Yang.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm sorry. Those are -- those are the three requirements for Article III standing, but there's an additional requirement of adverseness. None of those three requirements that are -- that are set forth in our -- in our opinions deal Alderson Reporting Company with adverseness. That's a separate --  separate issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's what's being challenged here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There has to be injury, in fact, okay? It has to be attributable to the --  to the defendant, okay. And the court must be able to remedy it. None of those three requirements, which are the classic requirements, deals with the quite separate point of adverseness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If somebody comes in and says, yes, you've been injured, the court could provide relief, but I --  I agree with all of that, and here is the money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Yang, I --  I --  I do understand what you and Petitioner --  Respondent's counsel are arguing, which is someone, a judge, has to say, at some point, this is in fact complete relief and enter a judgment for that complete relief. That's your argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. Parties could stipulate. If they --  if they accept an offer of settlement, that's like a stipulation saying, this is complete relief for us. There's no adversity. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. It --  it has authority to enter that even though the case is moot; right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But when there's a Alderson Reporting Company settlement offer which has been accepted, the court can nonetheless issue a judgment enforcing that settlement, no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So --  so even though the parties have no adverseness at all and they all agree on what the outcome should be, but we want a court to go into this matter which we've all agreed on because we want a judgment? Is --  is --  is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: --  the Article III adverseness requirement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think it's remarkable.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What happens on other grounds of lack of jurisdiction? What if the plaintiff has no injury? There is no injury. The court --  in other words, the --  the requirements for Article III jurisdiction that you rehearsed. What happens in that case? No jurisdiction for another reason besides mootness?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what if the -- the plaintiff comes in and says, well, I want --  I want a judgment? Or because what other --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: --  bases, or I want --  I want --  whatever reason. I mean, they're -- we're insisting on a judgment even though, arguably, depending upon the scope of the offered relief, the case Alderson Reporting Company is moot.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Other cases, you say they dismiss it as -- why -- why doesn't that go to trial? Or -- or you get the benefit of the court determination?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think you're wrong. I think if there's no standing, I don't think you get dismissed as moot. I think you get a judgment for the defendant because the plaintiff has no standing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Indeed. So -- so the fact that the court issues judgment has nothing to do with whether there's Article III standing, whether there's mootness or not. You can enter the judgment even though there's no Article III standing.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So even if a -- even if the plaintiff is given all the relief to which he is entitled, you say the plaintiff still has a right to involve the Federal court in that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And I was -- I -- I can't say "that controversy," because you still have to Alderson Reporting Company right to call --  go into Federal court and say, I know, Federal court, you're busy with a lot of things, but I still want you to hear my case even though I've gotten everything I could get.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So is a --  is a plaintiff who has been given all the relief that he's requested, in the view of the United States, an adequate class representative?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, of course it can. I want to know what the position is.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Garre, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Relying on a provision of the California Civil Code, which was quite different from Rule

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Garre, I am so confused by your argument. You get to say, on your own, unilaterally, I offered you complete relief, even though, right or wrong, the plaintiff is asking for a particular injunction and a particular attorney's fee. You, without any judicial interpretation, intervention, get to moot the case on your terms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What happens if you hadn't done that? Let's assume that he was entitled to attorneys' fees. Who's -- when does that decision get made and by whom?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That a complete offer Alderson Reporting Company has been made?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That -- that is -- that's all I needed for you to say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Okay? Let's stop there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So a court gets involved -- a court gets involved no matter what. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. So you offered and they wanted an injunction. The court can enter that injunction. I'm putting aside the class action. I'm --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The court can't -- all right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But it can't just say the case is moot and not enter the injunction. The terms of the settlement, the terms of the lawsuit, were that an injunction would be issued and you'd pay $1,500; correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- poor usage of words, counselor. It can't enter a judgment --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- unless there is jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Accepted. Accept -- accepted settlements.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Not settlement of the law. Justice --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- Sotomayor suggested, move this affirmative defense of payment to summary judgment.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
